Travelling Tips to Ganapatipule



A Must Visit for Everybody
Post by Rajesh | Mumbai | Nov 8, 2006
We took an overnight train from CST (VT) Konkan Kanya Express which leaves at 11.00 pm and reaches ratnagiri at 6.35 pm. The timing of the train is conviniet since u reach ganpatipule before 9.oo am which would be ur check in time.From ratnagiri station u cand catch a ST BUS for ganapatipule or ask a couple of autos. they charge around RS 350 for one way trip, but it is worth it. While returning we booked ourselves on the Mandovi express which comes from Goa and reaches ratnagiri at 2.35 pm and reaches Mumbai at 9.00 pm. Trains r usually late though since the konkan railway runs only on a single track.
Read full review 







Serene, Calm, Enchanting and Enticing
Post by Rinaldo | Mumbai | Jun 30, 2009
Reaching Ganapatipule - The drive from Mumbai to Ganapatipule takes at least 8  9 hours covering a distance of 375 kms. It is well connected to Mumbai with Ratnagiri being the station closest to Ganapatipule.
Temperature- The day temperatures in the area range between mid 20 to 30 degree Celsius and is ideal to enjoy a dip in the waters. Nights though are cool and breezy. I must warn that the beach waters are highly salty and can easily lead to sun burn and skin pigmentation. I soon realised that the romance of the beach setting fades when you swim in its water.
Read full review 





Beach, beer and a 5km walk
Post by Shankar | Mumbai | Apr 26, 2008
Ganpatipule is an ideal weekend getaway from Mumbai and Pune. If you have a car, the journey (around 350 kms) should get done in 6-7 hours , marginally lesser for Puneites, marginally longer for Mumbaikars.
We did not have a car. We took the Janashatabdi from Mumbai, an ideal train to get there. It leaves Mumbai at the crack of dawn and touches Ratnagiri before 11 am. Ganapatipule is less than an hours ride by auto, so we were checking in by 12 noon. The autorickshaw guys charge a flat Rs 350.
For those on a budget, theres the bus option. You could take the excellent bus service from the rail station to Ratnagiri ST bus stand (7-8 kms), and find a bus from the ST stand to Ganaputipule. There is a bus almost every hour. The bus ride is a bit longer and lasts approximately 90-120 minutes. You could end up reaching Ratnagiri after 1 pm, which, if you ask me, is not the same as 12 noon.
A third option, if you can put up with night travel in a bus, is a direct ST bus from Mumbai or Pune. The ride is around 9-10 hours. A bus leaves Vashi at midnight, while there are buses from Borivli and Pune in the morning as well as the evening. You can check with the nearest MSRTC depot. The advantage of the ST is that you dont need to change buses to get there. The fare is also economical (Rs 175 one-way for standard STs) but I dont savour a night ride in a bumpy bus. I did when I was in college, but not any longer.
We stayed at the MTDC resort. The location is terrific as the resort hogs the beach. It spans half a kilometer of the prime beach front and is adjacent to the Shree Kshetra Ganapati temple, which lords over the rest of the beach. The gates of the resort and the temple face each other, the temple on the south and the resort on the north.
The resort is divided into two sections, upper and lower. Separating the two sections is a hillock which is part of the MTDC estate. The two sections run like independent hotels, with independent receptions, room services and restaurants. It is wise to select your rooms depending on which section you would like to stay.
The section closer to the temple, and therefore closer to the main gate, is the upper or higher section. This upper section has more rooms and has a larger and better-stocked restaurant. It is 30-75 feet above sea level, depending on the type of room you take. The price of the rooms goes up with the altitude. The rooms closest to the main gate are the cheapest, as they are non-AC rooms in one-storey buildings. The most expensive rooms in this section, the Sea View Cottage, are at the highest altitude (75 feet). In between them are the Super AC row houses. Each type of room has an independent flight of stairs heading down to the beach.
The second section is nearly a kilometre away from the main gate. The path to this lower section skirts the hillock that separates the two sections. If you take an auto from Ratnagiri and have chosen the lower section, ensure that you take the auto right in. The lower section is at sea level, so you dont need a flight of stairs to reach the beach. The independent rooms in this section are called Konkani huts. These huts are barely 50 metres away from the beach and the windows in the huts have a breathtaking view of the ocean. For budget travelers, this section has tents. I wouldnt recommend the tents.
The lower section also houses an unimpressive ayurveda centre and a rudimentary water sport facility (read paddleboats and motor scooters). The restaurant here is a satellite of the main restaurant in the upper section. It is open air and is very close to the beach, making it ideal location for beer (Rs 100 a chilled bottle). On the flip side, some of the dishes available in the upper section are not available here.
Upper or lower, where to stay: We stayed in a Konkani hut. When I visit Ganapatipule again, I would opt for the Super AC row houses in the upper section. These are roomier than the Konkani huts: they have a little parlour inside beside the bedroom and toilet. They also have a sheltered verandah outside. The view of the sea from the altitude is breathtaking; the wooden benches in front of the row houses are breezy cuddling spots.
The only problem with these row houses is that you need to climb down 30-40 steps to reach the beach. On the way up the stairs is a shower in an alcove where you can wash the sand away.
I really wouldnt climbing up and down, but I can understand why some guests would find that inconvenient. The lower section is at sea level and senior citizens would find it easier on the knees.
My problem with the Konkani huts is that they lack the shower, the parlour and the verandah. You come out of the beach and you are into the room. You drag sand in with you. If you are driving there, you can always drive down to the lower section for a beer or for a dip, if stairs are discomforting.
The best thing about Ganpatipule is the clean beach and the cleaner water. Early March is a great time to visit as the place is not too crowded and the weather is pleasant. I can imagine it getting warmer in April and May. The sea is not very rough, either; if anything, perhaps a bit too gentle. There are warnings all over the beach cautioning you not to venture deep. The beach lacks a lifeguard, so you are pretty much on your own.
We returned to Ratnagiri to take the Janashatabdi back. On hindsight, the choice of train was wrong as we chugged into Mumbai around midnight. The MTDC check out is at 9 am. It would be ideal to return by the Netravati which leaves Ratnagiri at 10 am and reaches Mumbai by 5 in the evening. You have time to unwind before heading for work the next day. Those who dont have the luxury of the extra day could consider a return bus journey (the only option for Puneites, really). The ST stand is just outside the MTDC resort. There are also a few private buses that leave in the evening.
Read full review 





Paradise of western coast
Post by Sushil | Lucknow | May 31, 2006
From mumbai one can go to Ratnagiri by train , which is over night journey. After that one can hire a taxi to reach Ganpatipule. Mumbai to ratnagiri is 375 km and from ratnagiri to Ganpatipule is 50 km. Dont go deep in the sea. there may be under current in the water.
Read full review 





Place to lay back and enjoy
Post by Rajani | Mumbai | Feb 28, 2011
If you are going from Mumbai, just take Dadar Sawantwadi express. Get down at Ratnagiri and take a bus 30kms. You reach MTDC resort. If at all you plan to visit any other places by car/bus, make sure to take good driver/good car as roads are curvey and bit dangerous too
Read full review

Travelling Tips to Murud



Sun Sea and Sand
Post by Ashutosh
It is advisable to travel to this place in your own car. There is not much of a public transport system available here. This place is some 45 km further away from Ali Baug. From Pune, it is around 230 km. If you are travelling from pune then take the exit to khapoli and from here take the road to Pen. This is a short route but the road is in a bad condition. I will advise you to go to Panvel and take the Goa high away. You will save lot of time.
Read full review 





From sand castles to dolphins
Post by Salma | Pune | Dec 10, 2011
Its a 7 hour journey...Leave real early in the morning to reach in goodtime for lunch... You need to inform the resort so that they can accordingly arrange food for all...Teh distance is too huge especially for small children...the roads are ok...
Read full review 





A peaceful weekend destination
Post by Wanderer | Pune | Mar 2, 2010
Dapoli (main town) is around 184 km from Pune. On Pune Banglore highway you have to take right at Bhor Phata which is just ahead of Khed Phivapur. The road takesyou straight to Mahad if you follow the sign boards. You have to cross NH-17 just outside Mahad and go straight to Dapoli through Latwan.
It will take almost 5 hours to reach since the road mainly goes through ghats. It's better not to start too early in the morning as it is difficult to drive through the ghats in the dark. You will reach by lunch time if you start at around 8 am.
Make sure your vehicle has enough fuel as there is hardly any fuel station once you leave the Pune-Banglore highway at least not before Dapoli. While coming back, try to leave by 4 pm is not before so that you can cross the ghat section before it's dark.
It's better not to visit Konkan during summer as the temperature and humidity both are on the rise. September to February should be ideal though post monsoon there are chances of land slide in some parts of the ghats.
Read full review 





Daploli vacation
Post by Nn | Pune | Jan 9, 2010
We went from Pune via Tamhini Ghat and returned via Mahabaleshwar. It takes about six hours to reach and eight hours to return through this route. Since our driver had advance information about Bhor Ghat being a bad route, we did not venture in it, although it is shorter.
Read full review 







Kashid beach
Post by Reality | Bangalore | Apr 28, 2006
Drive from Mumbai (5 + hours) or Pune. A less attractive alternative is to take the Catamaran from Mumbai to Alibag and then use local buses or autos to get to Kashid. Once the propsed bridge connecting Mumbai to the mainland goes up, the drive should not exceed 2 hours - so please pray for divine intervention on that one.
Read full review

Travelling Tips to Alibaug



Enchanting 'ALIBAUG'
Post by Tarun | Bangalore | Apr 13, 2009
How to get there?
Alibaug is easy to get to in about an hour by the combination of a catamaran/ferry from Gateway of India in south Mumbai (three hours) and then by bus from Mandwa jetty across the bay.
It is also accessible by road via Panvel in about three hours (124 km).
By Boat/Cataraman/Ferry-
There are three agencies that run ferry services/catamarans: PNP, AJANTA and MALDAR. The ferry/catamaran takes you to Mandwa from Gateway by the sea route and from Mandwa, buses of the respective agencies takes you to Alibag by road. Catamarans are small ships. The tickets (costing 40 or 50 rupees) have to be bought beforehand and it includes the fare of the ferry service and the bus, both combined. Suppose you catch the ferry run by AJANTA, then remember after reaching Mandwa, you should not be in a mood to roam around because you have to immediately catch the connecting Bus of AJANTA from Mandwa to Alibag. Or else you will be left behind only to wait for the next bus. AJANTA and MALDARs ferry services helps to enjoy the sea breeze while PNPs catamaran service takes you in a fully covered AC coach and as a result you can by no way enjoy the sea. Dont forget to collect a timetable of the services of each agency at the ticket counter at Gateway. The last catamaran that leaves Gateway is by PNP at 8:10 PM. If you wish you can also have a view of the sea from the top of the ferry during your travel by the sea. The guys may charge you 10 bucks extra for going to the top of the ferry. The view of the Taj and the Gateway from the sea is awesome and dont forget to snap them, although Photography is prohibited on the Ferry as per notice by the Navy. The skyline of Mumbai is worth getting snapped. BUT its wise and better to ask the ferry personnel beforehand or else you may land up surrendering your film roll etc with embarrassment. Avoid planning ur travel during monsoons because this ferry service is stopped for three and a half months during the monsoons. The time taken to reach Alibag from Gateway via Mandwa is around 2 hours. The catamarans are faster than the ferry service so if you catch a catamaran you reach faster. Small passenger service boats ply frequently between Mumbai and Mandwa or Rewas. They are cheap but take more than 90 min
By Road-
There are a number of buses plying round the clock from Mumbai, Parel, Dadar, Boriwali and Thane. Alibag is on the Mumbai-Goa route (not exactly - from Vadkhal - there is a diversion) and is also accessible by Konkan Railway. Get down at Panvel and you can catch a bus.
By Rail-
Only two options - Get down at Panvel (65 Km) or Pen (Only Konkan Railway - Get down at Ramawadi Station - 23 Km). You can catch a bus. I will not recommend this option.
By Air-
Mumbai is the nearest airport. (Approx - 110 Km). Pune is another one.(140 Km). Getting off at Pune is not a good choice. You don't get frequent buses and journey is horrible.
Read full review 





WEEKEND GETAWAY
Post by Ashok | Nasik | May 31, 2011
Best way to reach Alibagh is by road with own vehicle. The vehicle is a must for the getaways to the various beaches. During summer vacation boarding in ac rooms is essential due to mosquitoes. Lodges are easily available. Boarding with locals at their cottages (approved by MTDC)should be tried any review on the same.
Read full review 





Alibaug-A truly mesmerizing experience.
Post by Kishore | Mumbai | Nov 11, 2010
Best way to reach Alibaug is by catamaran starting from Gateway of India. A short trip lasting for about 45 minutes is very relaxing and you do not realize how time flies while admiring the Mumbai coastline as you leave. In a short time Mandwa shore comes into view where you have to get down. You have to carry your own luggage along the jetty upto the bus (fare included in the catamaran charges) which is about 5-7 minutes walk. Hence it is advisable to travel light. Reaching Alibaug takes further 35-40 minutes bus ride.
Read full review 





Good overall experience - Alibaug
Post by Sumit | Pune | Apr 4, 2010
Approx. 3.5 hours from Pune. We preferred the old Mumbai-Pune highway. Having food at the Toni Da Dhaba was an added attraction. Non vegetarians would just love this Dhaba. The prices although are as much as that of a good restaurant. The feel of a Dhaba is very much there. For some time we felt we were in our very own Punjab.
Read full review 





Romantic Destination.
Post by Sneha | Mumbai | Aug 30, 2012
Alibaug is 40min ferry form Gateway where they drop you to Mandwa Jetty and from there the Ferry service has there to go go to city. The other option is roadways where it takes 3-4hours drive from Mumbai. Traveling by ferry is convenient and fun as well. But the ferry's don't work inn the rainy season so people have to cum by there own cars or the St service buses.
Read full review

Travelling Tips to Kashid Beach





Small is Beautiful - Laid back beach town
Post by Shagun | Nagpur | Jan 19, 2011
The roads are very nice to get to Kashid from both sides. The sea would follow you on one side all the way. Its about 170kms from Pune and 135 from Mumbai.
As for the stay, there are a few hotels around, but the ideal thing to do is the Home-Stay experience. You can stay in proper mud houses with clay-tile roof and enjoy the feel.
Warning - Theres not much to do around the town or th beach, so make sure you carry some source of entertainment, like a book, ipod some sport gear.
The Mantra would be to just relax and lie back, after all its a Weekend to Chill.
Read full review 





Drive to Kashid
Post by Abhik | Pune | Nov 1, 2010
If you are driving from Mumbai:
Go to Panvel -> Palaspa Phata (take left) -> drive through Karnala -> Reach Khopoli -> Reach Pen -> Take diversion to Nagaon (before reaching Alibag) -> Take right from Revdanda
IF your goin from Pune:
Go to Lonavla -> Take khopoli exit (from expressway) -> Turn left at the 4 point crossing just after khandala (road towards Khopoli) -> Rest is same.
Else you could go via Paud road:
Road beside Up and Above restaurant -> Toll plaza -> Tamhini Ghat -> reach NH17 to Goa -> Go towards Mumbai on this highway for about 500 metres and take left to Kolad -> Reach Roha -> Reach Revdanda -> Go straight from Revdanda.
Read full review 







For a Fishy Rejuvenating Experience
Post by Ranee | Goa | Nov 15, 2007
Kashid is a beach town on the shores of Arabian Sea, in the North Konkan region of Maharashtra, India. It is located 30km from Alibag and 135km from Mumbai on the Alibag-Murud road.
The train connectivity is not very good but the arrival of the Konkan Railway has ensured that this area is now more accessible.
The road access is very good and the drive on the meandering konkan coast is pleasant
	160 km from Mumbai
	135 km from Thane
	110 km from Navi Mumbai (Vashi)
	170 km from Pune (via Mulshi)
Buses:
	Buses ply regularly between Mumbai Central - Murud -halt at Kashid
	Buses ply regularly between Thane  Murud- halt at Kashid
	Frequent services are available for Alibaug from Mumbai, Thane. From there buses are available for Murud which halt at Kashid village
Very secluded so go in a group. Cell phones do not work.
Read full review 





Kashid Beach
Post by Omkar | Pune | Nov 5, 2012
Kashid beach can be reached easily as it has easy access from the major cities of Maharashtra via the roadways. The guests can opt either of the route from the below mentioned route whichever is convenient for them to commute easily and safely.
 170 km from Pune via Mulshi, or
 The Khapoli  Pune Mumbai expressway, which is around 170-180 km from Pune
The better way to opt for commuting to the Kashid beach is using the Khapoli  Pune Mumbai expressway as it provides convenience with better road conditions as compared to the Mulshi route.
By Air: The nearest airport is Mumbai
By Rail: The closest railhead using the Konkan railway is via Roha railway station. Roha is 122 km from Kashid. You can even get down at Pen station using same railway line as pen is 60 km from Kashid.
By BUS: All buses that ply between Mumbai central - Murud halt at Kashid
Read full review 





BEST VACATION DESTINATION IN MAHARASHTRA
Post by Shruti | Mumbai | Sep 14, 2011
From Mumbai, Kashid is a 3 hr drive. The best part of Kashid is that it is very close to mumbai and a person does not need to spend a bomb and go to Goa to be on a clean beach. Pack some beach clothes, carry your sunscreen and enjoy a relaxing time at Kashid.
Read full review

Travelling Tips to Dahanu



Serene place
Post by Prachi | Mumbai | Jul 30, 2012
Carry water /food during travel.The way from Mumbai does not have many eateries coz its highway throughout.Once you enter from the main highway into the rural patch,you cant find any food/water.Its just road.
Read full review 





The Cleanest Beach Destination
Post by Anand | Mumbai | Jan 28, 2013
There are various trains from Mumbai & Ahmedabad/Vadodara/Surat that halts at dahanu Station. Its just 2hrs from Mumbai, on the way to Gujarat. From Dahanu Station, you can take a private rickshaw for Rs.50 to Dahanu beach or shared auto for Rs.10 per person. You can carry some veg food if you are pure vegetarian or you can come back to Dahanu Station for restaurants. Carry your sun glasses & some woolen clothes as it was cold in Jan.
Read full review 


Read more reviews

Travelling Tips to Gorai



Gorai - Mini Goa near Mumbai
Post by Great_traveller | Mumbai | Jan 10, 2012
1)By Public transport: Well connected to Mumbai suburb's Borivali station west with regular buses to Gorai Bus terminal.BEST Bus #294 takes you directly to Gorai jetty which otherwise is a short walk from Gorai bus depot.
2)By Own vehicle : The roadway route to Gorai exists....but its a long drive through diversion at NH8 via Bhayander-Uttan-Gorai..about 45 minutes.
TRAVEL WARNINGS: Swimming should be avoided at some of the unsafe beaches in the vicinity. Need to negotiate rates for carts and rickshaws beforehand on island unless you want to be taken on a joy-ride ;) !
Read full review 





Family Beach
Post by Nilesh | Mumbai | Dec 18, 2012
Keep Towels handy as the hotels may have damp ones. Travelling from borivali is an experience. Take a road route to Gorai Creek fom borivali / kandivali station, take the local ferry across and drive to beach in a rickshaw or tonga. if you are going for day trip be sure to return early in evening as ferry and buss services fro Bhayander station stop.
Read full review 





Less bad amongs the worst
Post by Abhijit | Mumbai | Dec 11, 2012
A lane going towards beach from uttan road is very narrow. if you are driving, be careful. Tank your vehicle sufficiently. Nearest fuel station is at least 20 Km away. Do swim but dont venture too much inside. Sea is deep here. and i haven't seen any life guards anywhere. 
Read full review 


Read more reviews

Travelling Tips to Port Blair



A place which reveals the extreme patriotism...
Post by Pamp | Chandigarh | Jun 6, 2011
Travel tips :
**Always Carry a Sun good Sunscreen lotion, Sun Glasses, some snacks and water with you.
**Carry some extra clothing while going to any beach.
How to reach :
From Kolkotta and Chennai both Ship and Flights are available. For Ship either you need to reach one of the ports a week before or contact to any trip maker for the relevant arrangement.
Travel Warnings :
If you are using a Reliance mobile connection then you need to switch it for some other one like Airtel, Vodaphone or BSNL,...as their is no Reliance coverage at all.
Preferred connection is Airtel and BSNL.

Read full review 





My experience at Port Blair
Post by Abhay | Indore | Nov 20, 2012
Flights operate from Chennai, Kolkata and Bhuvneshwar. Please plan you trip nicely and keep margin for bad weather otherwise you would miss a thing or two. In worst conditions, please do visit cellular jail and jolly buoy island.
Read full review 





Exotic Andamans
Post by Krishnan | Bangalore | Jan 20, 2011
Air travel is recommended as a time saver. A good lot of travel portals, offer good package deals, which are economic. Plan 2 to 3 months in advance to derive the benefit of low tariff. Carry only cotton stuff and informal and casual dress. Carry an umbrella and sun lotion with a spf factor of 60. Not advisable to go with chidren aged below 5, as they may not enjoy. To havelock, go by MV Markuzz. Pl go with empty or light stomached, as chances of vomitting are very high. Pl carry fresh lemon, poppins and anti vomitting tablets.
Read full review 





Amazing Andman
Post by Anand | Noida | Dec 23, 2012
Travellers flying into the Andaman & Nicobar Islands have to first arrive at Port Blair before taking a boat/ferry to any of the other islands. Frequent flights ply to Port Blair from Kolkata and Chennai.Taxis and auto rickshaws are available for the journey into the main city.
Read full review 





Andaman - Must Visit Destination
Post by Alok | Delhi | Dec 11, 2012
There is no direct flight from Delhi to Port Blair. I believe the shortest destination is via Calcutta. Secondly plan for your accommodation in advance else you need to pay little higher and there will not be any scope of negotiations. While in Port Blair City travel by auto not by taxi as any destination within city will not be more than 5 mins journey and taxi will charge Rs, 700-800 wherein by auto you can travel in maximum Rs. 30-40.
Read full review

Travelling Tips to Havelock Island





THE PARADISE OF INDIA
Post by swastik73 | Kolkata | May 12, 2007
1) Fly to Port Blair from Kolkata or Chennai.
2) Reach Havelock either by Helicopter(should be booked well in advance) or Steamer.
3)The return Launch from Havelock comes in the evening (18:00 hrs - 18:30 hrs) so if you are coming by Sea you should make arrangement in Hotel at Port Blair well in advance (Check in time of Hotels at Port Blair 8:30-9:00 hrs).
4)If you afraid of water do not come to Havelock, you will get bored.
5) Although there had been no accidents but it is advisable not to travel to Havelock during Monsoon for people who are not brave enough in relation to water.
Travel Tips:
1) Carry Cash, because Credit Cards are rarely accepted.
2) Remember there is no ATM at Havelock Islands
3) Always carry a stick at night to protect yourself from stray dogs.
4) Do not venture out in the Forest at night - Snakes
5) Listen to the locals and pay heed to their advice.
6) Have plenty of Liquor of your Choice. Liquior is very cheap
7) You can hire a cycle, travel by auto or bus or even hire a car as per your pocket and convienence.
8) If you are hiring Motor Bike/ Moped please check the condition of the Bike. If you donot check it, it may develop trouble and you may be required to pay substantial amount to repair it. It is better to Walk or hire a cycle then to hire a bike with both physical and machine trouble.
9)
Read full review 





Emerald Isles
Post by Susmita | Mumbai | Aug 28, 2012
Closest Airport - Port Blair, India.
Avoid the Rainy season while planning your visit.
Boats come to Havelock from Port Blair each morning and return every afternoon.
Spending a few days on the island allows you to soak in the atmosphere. Carry a good supply of mosquito repellent and Sun block (not sun screen) if you do not want a severe tan or sun burns.
Cotton clothes, floaters, swimming and diving gear are essentials.
Let the hotel people arrange your taxi and boat - share the same with others to split the cost or don't if you want the vehicles at your beck and call.
The boat men run many trips after dropping you to a destination so be firm in your arrangements and agreement. People are simple and helpful and politeness goes a long way.

Read full review 





Enchanting Havelock
Post by Kalyan | Pune | Apr 3, 2012
Once you reach the island via catamaran Makruzz (fare IR700 one way) or Govt. Boat (fare slightly less) it is advisable to hire services of a travel vehicle. Autos are available but are a pain to deal with; otherwise hire a two wheeler on a daily basis ( fuel to be bought from roadside shops - high price) or a bicycle if you can manage to rough it out. There are no street lights - and roads are not too wide. Hence it is better to walk to the jetty or the small bazaar after sunset.
Read full review 







Paradise Island
Post by Aniruddha | Kolkata | Mar 21, 2011
Take ship to go there from Neil Island or Port Blair.Government ship(Fare Rs 250/- 2 hours) as wells as Private ship Marks(fare Rs 750/- 1-15 hours) is there. Also You can avail sea-plane to reach there from Port blair. You can have a beautiful Arial view of islands. capacity of Seaplane 9.(fare Rs2300/-)It will take off from sea and land on sea. Carry suncream, sunglass, light cotton tea shirts and mosquito coils or liquidators and Chap pals.
Read full review 





The Emerald Islands of the Andamaans
Post by Neeraj | Delhi | Feb 17, 2011
Flights usually reach Port Blair in the morning. If you are lucky, you can catch the McCruze, a privately owned ship which reaches you to Havelock in 90 minutes. Its expensive though at Rs. 650, 750, and 1000. The government ferry is much cheaper at Rs. 200 but takes 2 and 1/2 hours and runs only in the afternoons. There is also a sea plane now, at Rs. 2000 per person, seats only 9 people allowing only 5kg. baggage but affords an areal view of the islands and takes only 20 minutes.
Go armed with a good sunscreen cream, hats and sunglasses, and mosquito repellents.
Read full review 


Read more reviews

Travelling Tips to Neil Island



Paradise on earth
Post by Tony martin | Chennai | Jun 24, 2012
Take the Govt Ferry from Port Blair. You might get to see Dolphins if you are lucky.
You can also arrange for private boats from havelock, i think. Barefoot provides day tour to Neil including snorkeling for around 1000per person i think.

Travelling Tips to Chatham Island





Chatam Saw Mill
Post by Prabhakar | Mumbai | Dec 28, 2010
Very simple way to reach. Most of the local buses terminate at Chatam Saw mill. All these buses move around the Portblair town, so one can get into the bus from any where. The place is close to one of the Jetty and hence, have a great view of Large ships at a close distance.
Read full review 


Read more reviews

Travelling Tips to Nagarjunasagar





Perfect weekend destination
Post by Tanveer | Hyderabad | Feb 28, 2012
I covered the sight-seeing places in this way:
Started from hyderabad at around 5AM
Reached a small town on the way around 7:30AM had a good local breakfast
Reached Sagar around 8:30AM, and to the boat house in another 10 mins.
The first boat starts at 9:30AM so I had time to drive to Anapu which is 8KM from the boat house, this place has some Buddhist excavations preserved here, and the garden and scenery around hills and dam waters is very good for eyes.
Reached back to boat house by 9:20AM, there was not much crowd so they issued the tickets a little late and the boat started by 10AM
Reached Nagarjuna Konda and back at 1PM.
Drove back to Vijay Vihar (this resort is ~15KM from boat house)
Had the lunch there and checked-in to the room I had booked (booking online from APTDC site)
Started to Ettipotala falls around 4PM - This falls is ~20KM from resort.
I reached the falls around 5PM, nothing much to see here except the falls and this falls is lighted up with lights after dark, I enjoyed seeing the falls at night in the colored lights.
Reached back to Vijay Vihar at night, Dinner at a restaurant that is 1KM from Vijay Vihar
Next day morning took the steps down from the back of the resort that leads upto the dam waters.
This was a very lovely site to see the waters and the area around. The scenery was really awesome.
Checked out around noon and reached Hyderabad in evening.
Read full review 





Break from Hyderabad-Nagarjunasagar Dam
Post by Arti mukesh | Bangalore | Mar 27, 2008
.We both are happy to be staying busy, but we both needed a break from our schedule.
My husband needed a time off from his travel for work, with no Internet access. No cooking for me, easy laundry options and time together itself was welcome. It was a much-needed breather from the normal routine .
All things come to an end and so did our lazy, carefree weekend. It is said and I strongly believe that taking time off and to just not think anything allows one to think 200000000000000 times faster. But .Too much thinking can be just as bad as not enough, after allENJOY!!!!!!!!!!!
Read full review 







Good for a good weekend
Post by GV | Secunderabad | Jan 30, 2009
Lots of buses to Nagarjuna Sagar from Imliban and JBS from Hyderabad. Start at about 7 am to reach by 11 am with one stop for tea. Lots of towns and villages enroute so dont speed. Dont venture into waters because its infested with crocodiles. If travelling with families then Haritha Resorts is the best bet. It has a good view of the river and the rooms are spacious with swimming pool and play material for kids. The rates at Nagarjuna Resort on the other side of the Dam and Haritha Resorts or APTDC is same. Dont plan overnite stay at Ethipothala because its too remote a place with no crowd at all. Not worth it. Carry cool clothes because it gets hotter as day progresses. Carry mosquito repellents.
Read full review 







wonderful journey
Post by Shyam | Hyderabad | Dec 13, 2012
It is best to travel by bus & it is just 150 kms away from city which takes 4 hrs to go harsh driving on sagar roads lead to accident because it is single track road. wear helmet while driving on bike .
Read full review

Travelling Tips to Warangal



Warangal the temple town nesr Hyderabad
Post by Arti mukesh | Bangalore | Mar 27, 2008
What to Buy: I bought the Warangal carpet from Lepakshi Handicrafts Podduturi Complex. But there are many more crafts on display so one may choose as per their tastes
Just for your informationOther places are Khadi Gramodyog Bhandar, Subedari Hanamkonda (Khadi items), Warangal Dhurries Kothawada in Warangal, Pembarthy Brass Material Near Jangoan in Warangal District Cheriyal Scroll Paintings at cherial 30 kms from Jangoan in the Warangal District.
Sundays all shops are closed so plan accordingly
Fort Warangal Site Guide S. D Goush Pasha Tel: +91 9090107346.,,,,,,,,D. Ravinder Tel: +91 9390107212
P. Maheshwar 1000 Pillars Temple, Site Guide Tel: +91 9849236479
Ramappa Temple Site Guide G. Vijay Kuamar Tel: +91 0870 15-240161(PP) T. Venkatesh Tel: +91 0870 15-240176(PP)
Regional Tourist Information Bureau, Warangal Tel: +91 0870 2459201
We had a nice weekend break but it may not be a fun holiday so plan accordingly. All you lovers of temple architecture in HyderabadWarangal is a place worth a visit onceits very safe towards the end the thought of naxalites was so diluted that we just didnt remember that there was a fear lurking over us at the beginning of our holiday(I know there are too many temples). But enjoy the break!!!!!!
Read full review

No buses found on 2013-05-07

Best way to travel from Bangalore to Rajahmundry
 Rajahmundry is located at a distance of 818 km from Bangalore. Situated on the banks of the River Godavari, Rajahmundry is well connected to Bangalore by air, road and rail. However, the best way to reach Rajahmundry is by a direct flight from Bangalore, which takes around 3 hours. Rajahmundry Airport is located at a distance of 18 km from the city centre that can be travelled by auto-rickshaws, buses and cabs. Facilities like ATMs, medical services, book stalls, snack bars, tea-coffee bars and rest rooms are available at the Rajahmundry Airport.

Transport options from Bangalore to Rajahmundry
Bangalore to Rajahmundry By Bus: Take a direct bus from Bangalore to Rajahmundry, which takes around 13 hours. Rajahmundry Bus Stand is located at a distance of 5 km from the city centre. The places covered between Bangalore to Rajahmundry include Bangalore - 176 km -> Chittoor - 108 km -> Srikalahasti - 138 km -> Bitragunta - 91 km -> Ongole - 112 km -> Guntur - 149 km -> Tadepallegudem - 46 km -> Rajahmundry. Buses are suitable for individual travellers and backpackers. 

Travelling Tips to Rajahmundry



the beautiful Godavari
Post by Sampath kumar | Bangalore | Jan 2, 2011
The Rajahmundry town is easily reachable by bus or train from Hyderabad, Visakhapatnam or Vijayawada and so on. The railway line is well situated on the main and busy Chennai- Kolkata(Howrah) line with many fast trains passing throuhg it. By road also it is situated on the famous 6 lane NH 5 highway. The cabs are available at reasonable rates to make visits to the surrounding famous shrines/places.
Read full review 





A city on the banks of River Godavari
Post by Sarma
Rajahmundry is well connected to Chennai, Bangalore, Hyderabad,Delhi and Kolkata with direct express trains. One can travel to the city by direct flight from Hyderabad and Visakhapatnam. Cabs can be used for local travel. Avoid the period July- September as that is the rainy season.
Read full review 





Due to the Godavari River the place is worth visiting.
Post by Narendra  | Indore | Mar 5, 2013
Do not venture to Rajahmundry specially in Summers. It is very hot there. Can travel by train or busess. Southern Railway going to Vijayawada & Kakinada touches Rajahmundry.
Read full review 







Rajahmundry and Papikondalu
Post by M.raja
If provided sufficient time and travelling on own vehicle, don't miss Maredumilli and Rampa water falls on the way to Badrachalam. Great place for nature lovers. Thick forest and water falls. Don't miss bongu-chicken.
Read full review

Travelling Tips to Nizamabad



Hotel at Basara
Post by Bala | Hyderabad | Sep 7, 2012
Beautiful road from Hyderabad (NH7). There are not many sign boards to reach Basara from Nizamabad town and need to check with locals to to pick the correct route
Read full review 


Read more reviews

No buses found on 2013-05-07

Best way to travel from Bangalore to Anantapur
The distance between Bangalore and Anantapur, is around 220 km. It takes a little more than four and half hours of driving, from Bangalore to Anantapur. One can just follow NH7, crossing Devanahali, Chikballapur, Beggapalli, Budili, Penulonda and Nyamaddala. It is advised to have a stopover at Beggepalli for a tea break and fuel refills; because, after that, for 117 km, there is no decent place to stop. Though the road condition is generally good, except for when it rains, it is better to avoid driving at night. 

Transport options from Bangalore to Anantapur
Bangalore to Anantapur By Bus: Take a bus from Bangalore to Anantapur, which takes around four and a half hours. Anantapur Bus Terminal is located at a distance of around 11 km from the city centre and can be reached by taking a bus or an auto-rickshaw. Travelling by bus is economical and ideal for individual travellers and backpackers. 

Travelling Tips to Anantapur



Ooty - Coonoor- Pykara
Post by Sham | Bangalore | Nov 10, 2012
I would advise to go in colder seasons as it is non-seasonal time for the city and the expenses will be less too. Take a Volvo bus or a train. You will just enjoy it as it is getting darker, the fog covers the entire city and it is fascinating to watch that site.
Read full review

Travelling Tips to Lepakshi



Lepakshi, the archaeological marvel of southern India
Post by Ankur | Bangalore | Jun 11, 2012
We reached there in our car becasue we live in Bangalore and its quite near from Bangalore. However, bus and auto rickshaw service is available on NH7 and Lepakshi road junction.
Read full review 





One day trip to Lepakshi
Post by magicpotion | Bangalore | May 15, 2009
The roads are good through most of the journey. There is this left turn opposite a Mosque and a checkpost (No proper checkpost sign) to go towards Lepakshi. Need to be careful as to not miss this turn, better to ask a couple of locals after Bagepalli village for guidance. It gets very hot during summers and may be difficult to walk barefoot around the temple. You may wear socks to protect your feet and carry hats/sunglasses too. However, you need to remove the hat,socks etc inside the temple where pooja is performed.
Read full review 


Read more reviews

Travelling Tips to Badami





Golgumbaz - the tomb of your innermost Voices of Soul
Post by Vittal
Air: The nearest airport is Belgaum (205 kms), which is well connected to Mumbai and Bangalore. Rail: Bijapur is well connected to Bangalore, Mumbai (via Solapur); Hyderabad (via Solapur or Hotgi Jn); Hospet (via Gadag) ; Vasco da Gama (via Hubli and Londa). Bijapur railway station comes under the administrative control of Hubli division of South Central Railway (SCR) headquartered at Rail Nilayam, Secunderabad, AP. Road: Bijapur is well connected to many cities in south and west India, notably.
Read full review 





Badami, Aihole, and Pattadakkal
Post by Amit | Bangalore | May 3, 2006
All three destinations are quite far from each other. The destinations are accessible by medicore roads from Belgaum, Hubli, Hospet and Goa. The closest train station would be at Hubli.
Avoid travelling here in the summer due to extreme heat. Best time to travel would be the winter months. Clubbing Hampi with a visit to these destinations is strongly recommended.
Read full review 





Tour to Badami
Post by srini | Mumbai | Feb 20, 2011
If you are looking for road transport, Ilkal and Gadag are two favourite places connected to Badami. Ilkal is about 2h 15m drive from Badami and connected to most of the places.
While visiting Badami caves, beware of monkeys. They snatch away water bottles and any bags suspected to contain eatables. They are very very smart.
Read full review 





Kali temple in RON
Post by Narasimhan | Bangalore | Feb 24, 2008
22kms from Badami, as you go ahead you come to a village called RON....
do not get cheated by the hungry cabs....
its advisable to go by share auto... an unique experience....!
Read full review 





A historic place
Post by Muralidhar  | Hyderabad | Dec 26, 2012
There are historic caves, lake, temples around. Pattadikkal is a must see place because you can see different varieties of temple architecture in olden days in one place.
Read full review

No buses found on 2013-05-07

Best way to travel from Bangalore to Hampi
Hampi is situated at a distance of about 350 km from Bangalore. The former capital of the Vijayanagar Empire, Hampi is well connected to Bangalore by railways and roadways.
However, the best way to reach Hampi from Bangalore is by train, an overnight journey. The route is served by several trains, including express trains which are operated by the Indian Railways. The stations on the route have basic passenger facilities like drinking water, restrooms and eating joints serving snacks and local food.
Travelling Tips to Hampi



The Kishkindha kingdom of Mahabharata
Post by Priyanka | Bangalore | Jul 16, 2011
I travelled from Bangalore and took a KSRTC bus, reached in about 6-7 hours. The bus stop is around 10 kms before Hampi. From there you have frequent sharing-autos and individual autos too. Or there is a bus that goes to and fro every half an hour.
Read full review 







Peace!!
Post by Savio | Bangalore | Feb 9, 2011
If you are travelling from Bangalore, please be warned that the road till Chitradurga is brilliant. But after that, be prepared for what I would call, the worst experience of my life. Unfortunately for me, when I booked my bus tickets, only the last sleeper was available. In the middle of the night, it felt like I was suffering from an everlasting seizure. This carried on till I got to Hospet. Got down from the bus feeling all mixed up. On my way back, the bus driver told me that the government will be repairing this road soon. Considering its on the way to a World Heritage Site, it should have been done a long time back. But I wouldnt want to comment on that aspect. So please try and avoid this road.
In Hampi, if you want to get to the other side of the Tungabhadra, please be informed that this place is accessible by a small boat which runs every 5-10 minutes and the last trip is at 6 P.M. Each trip costs you Rs.15. The only other way is you need to go to Hospet and from there its around 30kms which means youll be travelling close to 45kms. Take the boat. It just takes 2 minutes.
Apart from this, there is nothing else you need to be worried about. People here are friendly and you can get around pretty easily.
Read full review 







Heritage at every footstep...
Post by wanderlust | Bangalore | Jan 8, 2010
From Bangalore there are various buses plying towards Hampi. Even if you don't get a direct bus,you can take any bus going to Hospet or Chitradurga and then change over to a bus for Hampi.
Read full review 





Visit to Vijaynagar ruins...Hampi
Post by Sudarshan | Bangalore | Jun 7, 2009
The best way to travel from Bangalore is by train. It is the most safe, cheap and relaxed way to travel. There is a train 'Hampi Express' that's available every night 10:30 PM and reached the Hospet by morning 8 am. Hire an auto, negotiate and you should get a price of Rs 100 or less to get u to Hampi, 15 kms from here.
Read full review 







The Forgotten Dynasty: Wonderfully historic, Real.
Post by Sanila | Bangalore | Mar 5, 2009
From Bangalore, Hampi can be reached by bus or train. All trains and most buses go till Hospet. You need to take another local bus or an auto to get to Hampi. The train ride is said to be longer than necessary, so if you're strapped for time, take a bus. Do make your bookings (both journeys) in advance.
Accommodation is plenty. I suggest not to make reservations ahead. The norm is to get there and check out 2 or 3 places and take a call.
Hampi has frequent power cuts, so make sure your phones and camera batteries are well charged.
Wear lose light cotton clothes and good comfortable footwear. You will be walking about quite a bit.
Be careful of touts.. these include guides,auto drivers and middle men working for guest houses. Avoid carrying valuables on this trip. Drink plenty of water to avoid getting run down by the heat.You must carry good sun screen , a hat and shades.
There are lots of monkeys at the ruins. They are not friendly!
Read full review 


Read more reviews

Bangalore to Hassan on

No buses found on 2013-05-07

Best way to travel from Bangalore to Hassan
The distance between Bangalore and Hassan, is almost 190 km. It takes a little more than four hours, to reach Hassan from Bangalore. The best way to reach Hassan from Bangalore, is by driving oneself. From Bangalore Railway Station, take the Tumkur Road i.e. NH 4 towards Yashwantpur. Keep driving on NH 4 for 30 km, to reach Nelamangala. After crossing Nelamangala, turn left onto NH 48 and drive for 44 km more, to reach Kunigal. Continue on the NH 48 and after 72 km from Kunigal, you will reach Channarayapatna and from there, Hassan is just 40 km away on the NH 48.

Transport options from Bangalore to Hassan
Bangalore to Hassan By Bus: Take a bus from Bangalore to Hassan, which takes over 4 hours. Hassan Bus Stand is around a kilometre away from the city centre and can be reached on-foot or by an auto-rickshaw. Travelling by bus is ideal for backpackers, youngsters and individual travellers. 

Travelling Tips to Hassan



swiss of india
Post by doc b
Hasanis well connected by road from bangalore,mysore and mangalore.
Trains are there from mysore and bangalore. Roads are well connected to all major cities.
As hotels are limited make your booking in dvance.check the home stays at Sakleshpur for comfortable Indian hospitality and authentic malnad cuisine.
Read full review 





Stay in Hassan\'s southern star 
Post by Aishwarya | Bangalore | Dec 5, 2012
Good roads, from bangalore to Hassan.. Dont take roads from Hassan to shiradi ghats.. Pathetic shiradi ghat road... Gundya, subramanya to uppinangadi roads r decent enough
Read full review 





Stay at Belur to visit Chennakesava Temple
Post by Sreenivasa | Mumbai | Jan 29, 2011
Hassan could be a base, as roads to / from Belur/Halebid & shravanabelagola are good. Road route via Arsikere are with lot of potholes and public transport is crowded and intermittent.
Read full review

Best way to travel from Bangalore to Mysore
The distance between Bangalore and Mysore, is almost 140 km. It takes a little more than two hours, to reach Mysore from Bangalore, by road or rail. Though the roads are very wel laid and have few traffic jams, the best and fastest way to reach Mysore from Bangalore, is by train. The Shatabdi takes just two hours to cover the distance. Though the fare is bit high, it provides with food and water. For a single adult in an AC Chair Car, the fare is Rs. 595. There are other trains running between the stations as well, almost on an hourly basis.

Transport options from Bangalore to Mysore
Bangalore to Mysore By Bus: Take a direct Karnataka State Road Transport Corporation (KSRTC) bus from Bangalore to Mysore that takes around 6 hours. The KSRTC buses from Bangalore to Mysore depart every 5 minutes. Bus Depot of Mysore is located 5 km away from the city centre. You can hire an auto-rickshaw to reach the city centre from bus depot. It is a suitable option for individual travellers and backpackers. 

Travelling Tips to Mysore





Cultural Bliss
Post by Savio | Bangalore | Mar 31, 2011
From Bangalore, take the Mysore Highway. I is just a 150 KM drive and the road is in an excellent condition. You will really enjoy the drive. For people relying on public transport, you can take a Volvo from Bangalore. Every half an hour a Volvo departs from Bangalore to Mysore. Then there is also a train which goes to Mysore from Bangalore,
Read full review 







Mysore - The Hub for the Variety Seeking Traveller
Post by Surej | Bangalore | May 30, 2006
Train from Bangalore not recommended unless you use the upmarket ones. Bus is comfortable or Car as gives you more mobility. Avoidable during the Holiday season and Dussera as it gets crowded . You can get very good bargains upto 30 percent off on Rooms in the Resorts around during the weekdays which have pools etc.
Read full review 





Sandalwood Heritage City
Post by KSR | Chennai | Jul 11, 2012
Bangalore,now Bengaluru,the Karnataka state capital with international airport and major railway and road transport network is 300kms.away with good railway and road connections to Mysore.
Read full review 





City of Culture
Post by KSR | Chennai | Dec 10, 2011
Transportation from Bangalore available every 15 minutes and hotels are aplenty for comfortable and courteous stay.My sore delights both the middle and upper class tourists.Oooty,the queen of the hills is not far away for the forest ride.
Read full review 





A short leap to Mysore & Srirangapattna
Post by Abhilekh | Hyderabad | Dec 2, 2011
For Mysore buses & trains are easily available from all over Karnataka, Nearest Airport is bangalore & mangalore.
For affordable & quick trip opt flight to Mangalore as Bangalore has hell lot of traffic prob & cab will not cost u much in mangalore as comparing to bangalore.
Select hotels which are within 1-2 km frm mysore palace as it saves time & money & city bus stand is near so by paying 15rs u can get city guide to follow buses routes & the bus service is really best.
Read full review

Best way to travel from Bangalore to Srirangapatna
Srirangapatna is situated at a distance of 125 km from Bangalore. Founded by the rulers of the Ganga dynasty in the 9th century, Srirangapatna is well connected to Bangalore by roadways and railways.
However, the best way to reach Srirangapatna from Bangalore is by road, a journey of around 2? hours. The places covered on the way are Bangalore -61km -> Channapatna -38km -> Mandya -26km -> Srirangapatna. On the way, there are several rest stops and dhabas. Options range from Kamath, Upachar to Caf? Coffee Day to restaurants dishing out north and south Indian fare. The restrooms are clean in most places. Petrol pumps of Indian Oil and HP are also available at regular intervals.
Travelling Tips to Srirangapatna



History Re-visited
Post by Hina | Bangalore | May 31, 2006
A little further down the Gumbaz takes you to the banks of the main Cauvery. Dip your feet into the water, or take a Coracle boat ride across the river.
A listing of the key attractions along with a route map is prominently displayed at all the sites. This is primarily a place for leisurely site seeing - people wanting a lot of action should stay away!
Srirangapatna is located about 15 kilometers north east of Mysore
Read full review 





A small historically important town
Post by Saty | Bangalore | Jan 1, 2012
Plenty of buses from Mysore, most Mysore bound KSRTC non-stops from Bangalore entertain a request stop at Srirangapatna, a very few trains stop at the Srirangapatna rail station. Autos are available in the rail station to take you around, but bargain beforehand.

Read full review 





Good destination
Post by Srikanth | Bangalore | Feb 4, 2013
Travel from Bangalore is about 3hrs by road and there are lot of trains to reach Mysore, Beware of Auto and taxi people if found ur new to place they will charge you more. Avoid swimming in the river.
Read full review

Travelling Tips to Sakleshpur



Lesser Known Attractions of Sakleshpur
Post by SS | Bangalore | Nov 21, 2009
There are trains to Sakleshpur from Bangalore and Mangalore 3 days a week. It is also only a 4 hour drive from Bangalore. So, get out on a weekend and enjoy the hills, greenery, waterfalls and the fresh air.
Read full review 





For all seasons - Sakleshpur
Post by Soups | Bangalore | Mar 20, 2010
Best to use your own vehicle. Just about a four hour drive from Bangalore and possibly 2-3 hours from Mangalore. Day train is available from Bangalore and lots of buses but you'll be strapped for transport unless you're planning to be at a homestay that provides you with a vehicle to move around. The monsoon is pretty strong in this region and although it is the most beautiful time, it can also be daunting for those who dislike wet weather.
Read full review 





Unexplored Gems of Sakleshpur
Post by SS | Bangalore | Nov 28, 2009
By road from Bangalore. Start early morning from Bangalore, you will reach Sakaleshpur by 11 am. There is a day train from Bangalore too. However getting around Sakaleshpur may be a challenge.
Read full review 





Good experience overall
Post by Ratham
This is specially for the people driving from Bangalore. The road is beautiful and irresistible to drive fast. However better to keep a check on speed. People drive really really fast, one's foolishness should not end up in another man's misery. 
Read full review 





one of the best place in sakleshpur to stay
Post by Priyanka | Bangalore | Feb 9, 2013
Its very near to bangalore so best destination if you are planning for 2-3 days trip. it takes exactly 4 hrs from bangalore to reach sakleshpur. the road is really great so problems at all. its better to start at around 7 am from bangalore so around 11-12 noon , you will be there and can enjoy great food in the swastha. On the way there are not many good restaurants except coffee day so its better you keep some food stuff for you.
Read full review 


Read more reviews

Best way to travel from Bangalore to Bellary
The distance between Bangalore and Bellary is almost 350 km. It takes almost eight hours to reach Bellary from Bangalore, by road. The best way to travel to Bellary, is by train. There are many trains that go to Bellary from Bangalore. Overnight trains are better, as they reach early in the morning and the traveller has the day at their disposal. The Hampi Express leaves Bangalore at 22:30 hours and reaches Bellary at 06:10 hours, the next day. The fare for a single adult in the sleeper class, is Rs. 170.

Transport options from Bangalore to Bellary
Bangalore to Bellary By Bus: Take a direct bus from Bangalore to Bellary, which takes around 6 hours. Bellary Bus Depot is located at a distance of around 2 km from the city centre and can be reached by bus or auto-rickshaw. Travelling by bus is economical and recommended for individual travellers and youngsters.

Buses From Bangalore to Bidar

Select bus 
Seat selection 
Passanger Info 
Payment

Bangalore to Bidar on






Calendar







No buses found on 2013-05-07

Best way to travel from Bangalore to Bidar
Bidar is located at a distance of 697 km from Bangalore. Renowned for traditional handicrafts and various art forms, Bidar is well-connected by railways, roadways and airways. However the best way to reach Bidar from Bangalore is by train, a journey of about 16 hours. The places covered during the journey from Bangalore to Bidar are Bangalore8 km -> Malleshwaram39 km -> Doddaballapur263 km -> Guntakal133 km -> Raichur135 km ->Sedam106 km -> Vikarabad74 km -> Zahirabad37 km -> Bidar. Facilities such as food stalls, waiting rooms, bookshops and ATMs are available on all the railway stations on the route.

Transport options from Bangalore to Bidar
Bangalore to Bidar By Bus: There is no direct bus from Bangalore to Bidar. However, several Govt luxury buses operated by Karnataka State Road Transport Corporation (KSRTC) are available via Hyderabad to Bidar that take around 16 hours. The Bidar bus station is situated at a distance of about 3 km from the city centre that can be covered by buses, taxis and auto rickshaws. Ideal for individual travellers and backpackers.

Travelling Tips to Idukki



Even a month is not enough to fully enjoy natures marvel - Idukki district
Post by Florien | Mumbai | Jun 6, 2008
Hire a private taxi with driver for the entire trip, it is worth it as you will always have transport when you require. Convenient airports are Nedumbassery at Cochin, Coimbatore and Madurai. Angamaly or Aluva nearest rail heads from the Cochin side. Very safe area so just the usual precautions required. Everyone in Kerala is aware of the benefits of tourism so they are all very courteous and friendly to visitors.
Read full review 





A little closer to heaven
Post by Jitin | Cochin | Apr 14, 2011
I travel mostly by car or bus. Any bus will do as long as it goes to your destination. Transfers aren't the easiest things and you can get lost if you aren't familiar with the place or have a language barrier. 
Read full review 





Vagamon - the number you are trying to reach is not reachable...
Post by Siraj | Bangalore | Jan 12, 2007
Vaagamon is in Kerala... So get to Cochin by flight, bus or train and hire a cab to take you to Vaagamon via kottayam.
In case you are driving yourself, the best vehicle to take you there is a Scorpio, Tavera or one of the 4X4s... I went in with my Baleno (a car well known for low ground clearance) and actually did not face too much of troubles...
Read full review 





'GAVI' in Idukki district in Kerala... a place to be away from the madding crowd
Post by Anooj
Entry to Gavi is highly restricted as it is a part of the Periyar Tiger Reserve in Kerala. Any unauthorised traveller will be turned away at 'Vallakadavu', the first forest check post. Prior permission from the forest department is requied to enter Gavi
Gavi is in Idukki district in Kerala . It is 28kms south- west of Vandiperiyar a town on N.H 220, the highway connecting Kollam and Madurai. Vandiperiyar is around 100kms away from Kotayam Town and is 14kms from Kumali. A one month advance booking is recommended as the rooms are always in great demand.
CONDACT DETAILS;
Tourist Facilitation Centre,
Holiday Home Complex
Kumily, Idukki District Kerala
Tele phone-04869 223270
Mobile phone - 94461 12034( Officer in charge)
or
The Divisional Manager,
Gavi Division,
K.F.D.C Ltd,
Gavi P.O.
Via Vandiperiyar,
Idukki District,
Kerala.
Contact person
Mr. Radhakrishnan.
Range officer in charge,
Green Mansion,
Gavi.
Mobile-9947 492399(between 4pm and 5pm only) .
Warnings.
Always obey forest rules and regulations and the instructions of the trained guides. Here we are the intruders in to the animal world.

Read full review

Best way to travel from Bangalore to Munnar
Munnar is located at a distance of around 469 km from Bangalore. The town is one of the most popular hill stations in Kerala and is well-connected to Bangalore by road and railways. However, the best way to reach Munnar from Bangalore is by cab, a journey of eight hours. The places covered between Bangalore and Munnar are Bangalore - 36km -> Hosur  49km -> Krishnagiri  113km -> Salem  273km -> Munnar. There are many fast food chains located on the route from Bangalore to Munnar like Dominos Pizza and Caf Coffee Day. Various South Indian vegetarian and non-vegetarian restaurants like Hotel Saravana Bhavan and Vivekananda Hotel are also situated on the way. Besides, there are numerous petrol pumps of Indian Oil and HP at regular intervals.

Transport options from Bangalore to Munnar
Bangalore to Munnar By Bus: Take a direct bus from Bangalore to Munnar, a journey of around 10 hours. Munnar bus stand is less than a kilometre from the city centre. Travelling by bus is recommended for individual travellers, young people and backpackers. 

Travelling Tips to Munnar



Be with your loved ones and not be disturbed
Post by prasy | Chennai | Feb 21, 2007
The best way to reach Munnar is to get to Cochin and then take the bus or hire a vehicle to reach Munnar in 3-4 hours. For local travel in Munnar request your hotel to organize a vehicle. There are star category hotels and resorts catering to the needs of tourists. Warm fleece jacket or woolen jumpers are necessary. Take an umbrella or raincoats because heavy clouds might appear quite suddenly over the mountains. After 5pm thick fog starts to envelope the hills sometimes giving zero visibility. Plastics are banned in Munnar panchayat. Avoid the monsoon season while visiting Munnar.
Read full review 





An Encounter with Pristine Nature
Post by Dipankar | Ranchi | May 26, 2011
Nearest Airport as well as Rail head is Kochi about 130 km away. Buses are available from Kochi, but hiring a cab helps in coming to close contact with nature, there are a number of unknown sightseeing points on the way to Munnar, none of them will be missed !
So what are you waiting for ? Pack your baggage and you are out for an encounter with pristine nature, you will never forget !!!
Read full review 







Fabulous Munnar
Post by Deepak | Bangalore | May 7, 2011
Nearest Airport and Railway station to reach Munnar is at Kochi, which is 138km away. The drive from Kochi to Munnar takes around 3.5 to 4 hours. The worst part of the journey is within Kochi, wherein you experience traffic jams.
The route to Munnar is scenic with abundant scenery. But the roads are full of sharp curves and you would be advised to eat lightly before travelling.
Read full review 





MUNNAR carpeted with tea gardens
Post by Rehana | Mumbai | Apr 30, 2012
The nearest airport and railway station to Munnar are at Kochi, which is 130 km away. Many buses and taxis ply to Munnar from Kochi, Coimbatore and Madurai. Nearest railway station to Munnar is Aluva which is 120 Kilometers away and Ernakulam Town and Ernakulam Junction which are 130 kms ...
But the ride is with lots of twists and turns so do take care of your medications.
Read full review 







A pleasant vacation
Post by VRV | Mumbai | May 10, 2011
Munnar is about 130 kms from Kochi railhead and the airport. Private taxis, and state buses can take you there in about four to five hours.
If one has own arranges car, then best is to stay a little away from the town to get the real feel of Munnar.
Read full review

Bangalore to Wayanad on

No buses found on 2013-05-07

Best way to travel from Bangalore to Wayanad
Wayanad is located at a distance of about 289 km from Bangalore. The town is popularly known as the 'Land of Spicy Hills and is well-connected to Bangalore by roadways, railways and airways. However, the best way to reach Wayanad from Bangalore is by road, a journey of about 5 hours. The places covered during the journey from Bangalore to Wayanad are Bangalore - 33km -> Bolare - 95km -> Bannur - 26km -> Mysore - 25km -> Najangudu - 22km -> Begur - 47km -> Mulehole - 23km -> Sultan Bathery - 24km -> Wayanad. On the way from Bangalore to Wayanad, several petrol pumps, roadside dhabas, multi-cuisine restaurants, South Indian food chains and ATMs, along with the Indo-American Hospital and State Bank of Travancore are located.

Transport options from Bangalore to Wayanad
Bangalore to Wayanad By Bus: Take a direct bus from Bangalore to Wayanad, which takes around 6 hours. Several private as well as government luxury buses operated by the Karnataka State Road Transport Corporation are available. The Wayanad bus station is situated at a distance of about 16 km from the city centre that can be covered by bus, taxi or auto-rickshaw. Ideal for individual travellers and backpackers. 

Travelling Tips to Wayanad





Adventurous Trip - from 14-04-2011 to 16-04-2011
Post by Sandhya | Mysore | Apr 23, 2011
Mysore --->55 Kms Gundulpet -----> 55 Kms Sulthan Bathery ----> 25 Kms Kalpetta - the district headquarters of Wayanad.
Kalpetta is a junction place for all sight seeing places.
We can get plenty of beautiful resorts and Home-stay in and around Kalpetta.
Roads are too good, well maintained for driving. 
Read full review 





Wayanad
Post by Kanchan | Bangalore | Jan 4, 2007
From Bangalore its a 6 hr drive through Mysore, Gundlupet, Sulthan Bathery and Kalpetta. Vythri has a lot of jungle resorts. One can choose to stay in a jungle resort in Vythri or in Kalpetta. We stayed in a jungle resort which was great, but the approach road is through a jungle and only a Mahindra jeep can do it. There is another route which is baiscally going through Srirangapatna, Hunsur, Nagarhole, Tholpetty and reaching Kalpetta. THe drive is very beautiful as there is a 70 KM drive through the jungle, but about 18 kms of the road is bad.
Read full review 





My Wayanad experience
Post by Sreejith
Do not travel with family in night in forest area. its dangerous if you find a wild elephant in roadsides. maybe they attack you and your vehicle. if you find any elephant on the way please stop your vehicle. do not switch off your vehicle headlight. if they come near you dont make any noise. wait till they moved to other places. Mananthavady to Kutta route and Muthanga to Gundalpettu route is most dangerous in night drive. avoid these route in night. access to Wayanad:Calicut to Kalpetta 75 kms Madikeri ( Coorg ) to Mananthavady 120 kms. Mysore to Sulthan Bathery 120 kms. Ooty to Kalpetta 117 kms. Most important town in Wayanad district with accommodation options Mananthavady, Sulthan Bathery Kalpetta and Vythri. From Kalpetta easy access to most of all important tourist places in Wayanad. 
Read full review 





Hill station
Post by Uma | Cochin | Jul 16, 2012
By Air: The nearest Airport from Wayanad is Karipur Airport of Calicut.
By Train- The nearest Railway station is Calicut & from Calciut have to either take a bus or a car by road which will minimum take 2-3 Hours drive.Best season will be from September to May
Read full review 





Wonderhill wayanad
Post by Rengarajan.n
Nearst airport,rail links is calicut. Lot of travel operators are available according to our budget. All months are good except rainy season I.e july to September.
Read full review

Travelling Tips to Nelliyampathy



Nelliyampathy and coffee blooms...
Post by Saji | Cochin | Apr 22, 2009
Route:Palakkad-Nenmara-Pothundi Dam-Kaikatti(at the top) -Pulayanpara
There are buses from Palakkad and if you have a vehicle you can reach Pulayanparra and unless if you are a four wheel drive,sturdy SUV owner you will have to avail the jeeps for visiting all the exotic places.
The jeep guys will take you for a night safari also at higher rates,but beware there might be an angry tusker on the prowl who is ever ready to overturn your jeep and practice stampeding.
Read full review 





awesome place to visit
Post by Senthil ramkumar | Salem | Nov 9, 2010
route No1: Coimbatore- Palakkad- Kudavayoo-kolangode
nice drive but slightly longer than the other(via Pollachi) u have to drive almost 100+ kms inside Kerala state. road from Kollangode to Nemarra is slightly irritating with lot of pot holes. roads in nemmara town isnt good either. ghat section from nemara to neliyampathy is awesomesingle sided indeed as u go further up u get to look at the view of poonthondi dam. many small water falls r seen on the way to. Roads aren't winding nor hectic.
Read full review 







Amazing Nelliyampathy Hills
Post by Biju | Bangalore | Jan 8, 2011
Nelliyampathy is in Palakkad District, Kerala. You can reach here within one hour from Palakkad. This beautiful hill station is connected with road from Kerala and Tamilnadu.
Read full review 





Visit to Nelliampathy
Post by Monica | Chennai | Mar 1, 2013
To reach nelliampathy, the best choice is to take our own car such that we can travel to every place possible at nelliampathy. Bus timings are frequent. If not, you can enjoy the ksrtc bus rides that go like roller coaster on the hills roads. 
Read full review 





Different experince we enjoyed
Post by K s singharavelu | Madurai | Feb 7, 2013
Traveling time is to reach before 4.00pm otherwise we have to face struggling passing thorugh mist coverage route from pollachi tamilnadu via kollencode and Nemmara from wher take left and travel nearly 35kms en-route one dam is there
Read full review

Travelling Tips to Vagamon



My Beautiful Vagamon visit
Post by Raja | Pondicherry | Jul 31, 2011
Warm clothes, Umbrella, better to take bubble top (water) if you are planned to stay for a long time, torch and buy some medicine available locally to protect you from leaches.
Read full review 





Vagamon - Feel near god
Post by Prakash kumar | Chennai | Sep 4, 2012
Take train to KOTTAYAM in Kerala. & you can hire a cab to reach Vagoman
(65km aprox).The roads are average.
There are no good hotels in Vagoman city. so carry your food from the resort
itself to avoid any disappointments
Read full review 


Read more reviews

Travelling Tips to Kalpetta



The mountain country
Post by Bijoy | Bangalore | Dec 3, 2011
Accessible by road from Calicut or Mysore from the western side. It's a 3 hr drive from Mysore through the Bandipur Santuary.
Avoid night travel on the highway because of winding roads that are scarry in the dark with the thick vegetation cutting your sight short. 
Read full review 





KALPETTA - unforgettable experience.
Post by Vv | Hyderabad | May 23, 2010
From BANGALORE to KALPETTA.
Early start is better 6.30 TO 7.00AM ( to avoid traffic of bangalore)
after 40 kms you will find restarant KADUMANE .
You can have break fast here . and you can proceed to Mysore. ( BAN-MYSORE 145 KM )
BY 11.00 AM You can go around Mysore have a look at CHAMUNDI BETTA, KRS DAM .
You can have lunch in an of the hotels on palace road. You cannot find hotels that easily in Mysore. As most of the hotels are on palace road.
You can leave Mysore by 2pm, it takes 3 hours to reach WAYANAD ; 145 KMS.
Always keep mineral water bottles/ fruits/ juices with you ( 3 to 4 minimum ) Once you leave mysore, you don't get anything to eat before wayanad.
from Mysore
You will NANJANGUD
then GUNDLUPET from here you have to take a right . ( ROAD shows towards KOZHIKODE( CALICUT) from Gundlupet - KALPET AROUNG 80 KMS
You can see BANDIPURA FOREST
MUTHANGA WLID LIFE SANCTUARY
then town of SULTAN BATTERY
before reaching KALPETTA.
Always drive in day time only to KALPETTA.
have a nice stay in kalpetta.
Read full review 





Visit to WAYANAD's heavenly abode at Kalpetta
Post by Samir
One can enter from Bangalore - Mysore national Highway . Bangalore to Mysore road distance is 120 km. From Mysore 60 ams drive will take you to Gundalpet. Another 55km drive will take one to Sultan Bathery. Further drive for 24 km will bring one to Kalpetta. If one visits from Kozhikode (calicut) side, then 64 km drive will bring him to Chundale via Vythiri and then to Kalpetta. It can also be accessed from Coimbatore- ooty, Gudalur, Sultan Bathery side . If one travels from Mysore side then he should cross the stretch of NH 212 in the forest to enter Kerala before dusk so as not to disturb the movement of animals accross the road. One should not park vehicle after 5pm on NH212 from Mysore to Muthanga(Kerala).
Read full review 





It's really Gods Own Country - lush green & nature fresh
Post by Balakrishnan | Bangalore | Sep 15, 2011
Its a decent drive through forest. area. Take care while driving...
Drive down from Bangalore - Mysore - Gundulpet - Kalpeta. Road condition is good except some potholes. 
Read full review 





God's Own country- Wonderful experience
Post by Venketash
Catch a train from Chennai to Kochikode from that take from road ways which will be easy. While returning take a bus from Kalpatta & you will reach to mysore from that you can catch shatabthi express full AC with snacks provided at the train itself. Enjoy 
Read full review 


Read more reviews

Kadmat . . Heaven on Earth . .
Post by Sahdev | Ahmedabad | Jun 8, 2009
Well i had gone on Star Cruise Libra . . I just got a day to spend at the island . . but i guess the trip on the cruise is worth enjoying. . once in a life time visit. . Must visit cruise for all the travel and party food freaks. .

Travelling Tips to Karaikal



Nice place with budget
Post by Raja | Chennai | Sep 3, 2012
From chennai to Karaikal 320 km Via
Pondicherry by bus route,There is
no frequent train from chennai to karaikal, only one or two trains available in a day.

Read full review 





Pilgirmage Tour
Post by Gopalakrishnan | Chennai | Dec 23, 2012
Cabs fare also very nominal, when compare to other tourist places. From chennai, direct train is available to karaikal.
Though, beach is there and not many people are there... There is no transport from town to Beach, except Auto Not advisable to stay in beach for outsiders, after 7.30 pm.
Read full review 





Karai trip
Post by Senthil
You came come by train, bus and car,
Train from chennai, eranakulam via TRICHY, Tanjore
For bus it covers most of the distinction in Tamil Nadu and some places in Kerala and Bangalore
Read full review 





Devotional Trip
Post by Rajiv
The town is well connected from Chennai & have connectivity to Kumbakonam, Tanjore. The place is not good during rainy days so avoid travelling during that time.
Read full review

Travelling Tips to Kanyakumari



Where the seas and the ocean meet
Post by George
If your base is Thiruvananthapuram or Nagercoil, Kanyakumari can be covered in a day. Else (or if you want to spend more time here), there are plenty of hotels in all budget ranges to spend a night or two.
Kanyakumari is well connected both by buses and trains. The nearest airport is 87 kms away at Thiruvananthapuram.
Read full review 





A MEMORABLE VISIT TO KANYAKUMARI
Post by Subrato | Bangalore | Oct 30, 2010
I suggest that you head direct to Kanyakumari, take a breather there for a few days and then visit to nearby places like Rameshwaram, Madurai, Thiruvanantapuram or even Kodaikanal. It can be arranged easily from the hotel itself or through travel agencies in abundunce at Kanyakumari.
Read full review 





The Calm but crowded Cape Comorin!
Post by Sunitha | Kanpur | May 26, 2011
BY Road, straight onto National highway 47 from Trivandrum, passing through Parrashala, Marthandam and Nagercoil. its a smooth drive even at night. The only tricky regio as about 5 km away from Kanyakumari, there is a crossing of NH47 and NH7. Picking up your route after the swirl is a challenge.
Read full review 





A visit to KANYAKUMARI is always an amazing experoence and that is why, I have made a visit after
Post by Subrato | Bangalore | Oct 29, 2010
Go straight to Kanyakumari and then take visits to Rameshwaram, Madurai or Thiruvanthapuram. It can be arranged from all hotels as well as travel agencies are also available.
Read full review 





Unforgettable experience.
Post by Kishore | Delhi | Nov 21, 2012
We have gone to Madurai by air from Delhi. From there, we took a cab for going to Rameshwaram and thereafter to Kanya Kumari. The journey from Rameshwaram to Kanyakumari was very beautiful with scenic views. You should be careful while traveling with small children.

Read full review 


Read more reviews

Travelling Tips to Madurai





The City that never sleeps..!!
Post by Arshat | Bangalore | Jun 29, 2010
Buses are available from almost all major cities and towns around. Or take a train. Try not to mess up with the people, they're good but the are pretty famous for their temper too..
Read full review 





A place of godess Lakshmi
Post by Ram
Its of your choice. Place is well conected with Chennai and any other part of India. But for all these near by places book a taxi.
For Dhanush koti you will have to share with local vechiles only.
Read full review 







City of God
Post by Karthick | Chennai | Feb 8, 2008
Please take cotton clothes with u, b'coz madurai is usually hot. 'Chitirai thiruvizha' is a month long festival celebrated in April, its a great experience to watch the holy wedding & car festivals.
Madurai is well connected by road, rail & air.
Read full review 





Post by Bhaskar  | Bangalore | Mar 29, 2013
Madurai is well connected by road, rail and air. By air, it is well connected to Coimbatore and Chennai. People traveling by flight have to stopover at Chennai and then travel to Madurai. The upgraded highway is another option which provides enhanced and faster access to the city
Read full review 





TASTE OF JASMINE CITY
Post by Subramanian | Hyderabad | Feb 3, 2013
Since this is close to rameswaram can take a holy dip and do the ancestral dues as well as visit keezakkarai where lord rama has done pooja for removing brhamahathi dosham. Also visit navagrahas which is in sea and made out from sand by lord rama and was made prior to his visit to srilanka. Also can visit tiruchendur by road which is also famous for murugan.
Read full review
